item.title: 2 Brothers Identified as Brussels Attackers; 3rd Suspect Is Sought
item.description: Ibrahim el-Bakraoui blew himself up at the airport, and Khalid el-Bakraoui carried out the suicide attack at the subway, Belgian officials said.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN, KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA and AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: What Obama Should Know About Macri’s Argentina
item.description: The U.S. must not overlook the new president’s cavalier attitude to democratic institutions.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: GASTÓN CHILLIER and ERNESTO SEMÁN
item.media:description: Protesters last month demanded the release of the prominent social activist Milagro Sala, who was arrested in January.

item.title: Blogger Gets Jail Term in Singapore for Posts Said to Incite Ethnic Hatred
item.description: The pregnant Japanese-Australian woman was arrested while on vacation in Singapore with her husband, who also faces charges.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Ai Takagi, 23, pleaded guilty to four counts of sedition over the articles carried on a website, called The Real Singapore, that she ran with her Singaporean husband, Yang Kaiheng.

item.title: Memo From Russia: Russia, Light on Cash, Weighs Risks of a Heavy Tax on Oil Giants
item.description: Times are so tight the Kremlin may soon dip into the one reserve it holds sacred: the funds its oil companies need to invest to ensure future production.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: A worker walking past a pump jack at an oil field near Nikolo-Berezovka, Russia.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Islamic State’s European Front
item.description: The world’s most dangerous jihadist group is in retreat in the Middle East. That’s bad news for Europe.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: DANIEL BYMAN
item.media:description: Iraqi troops advancing on a village near Ramadi, Iraq, with an Islamic State flag. The Islamic State’s military setbacks in Iraq and Syria mean it will need to win victories elsewhere.

item.title: Sinosphere: China Aims to Tighten Its Borders Against Foreign Place Names
item.description: A Chinese official said that names that “damage sovereignty and national dignity” would be targeted, a state news agency reported.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jackson Hole, a community in Hebei Province, on the outskirts of Beijing, mimics the aesthetics of Jackson Hole valley in Wyoming.

item.title: Cuba Says It Has Solved Racism. Obama Isn’t So Sure.
item.description: In a speech in Havana, the president noted America’s and Cuba’s similar struggles with racism, spotlighting an issue the Cuban government says is settled.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers painted fresh pavement in Havana on Saturday, the day before President Obama arrived in Cuba.

item.title: Global Crises Shadow, and Overshadow, Obama’s Foreign Trips
item.description: The White House has struggled to calibrate its message when violent events like the attacks in Brussels have arisen while the president is overseas.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER

item.title: Obama Visit Affirms Argentina’s Shift Toward Center
item.description: The president is also said to be seeking to firm up the United States’ position in the region, where China has been establishing a foothold.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN GILBERT
item.media:description: President Obama arrived in Buenos Aires early Wednesday with his wife, Michelle, and their daughters, Malia and Sasha.

item.title: Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 Investigators to Examine Debris Finds
item.description: The Australian authorities said they would try to determine whether two pieces from Mozambique and one from South Africa were from the missing plane.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.media:description: A piece of debris found in South Africa appears to bear the logo of the engine maker Rolls-Royce.

item.title: Brussels Survivors Say Blasts Instantly Evoked Paris Attacks
item.description: “My immediate reaction was, ‘We are getting attacked by terrorists,’” one witness said, echoing others who described explosions and carnage that wrenched them into thinking of the Nov. 13 killings in France.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY, JAMES KANTER and ANITA RAGHAVAN

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Does Obama Have This Right?
item.description: The president seems so intent on avoiding any Mideast invasion that he is underestimating the cost of his passivity.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

item.title: U.S. Strike in Yemen Kills Dozens in Qaeda Affiliate, Officials Say
item.description: The airstrike was the latest sign that the Pentagon is hastening its strikes against militants in the Middle East and Africa.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

item.title: Cuban Dissidents Praise ‘Closeness and Trust’ After Meeting With Obama
item.description: The president discussed human rights for nearly two hours with leading dissidents, including some who have criticized his policy of engaging with the Cuban government.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: FRANCES ROBLES
item.media:description: President Obama discussed human rights with leading Cuban dissidents for nearly two hours on Tuesday in Havana.

item.title: Strikes Claimed by ISIS Shut Brussels and Shake European Security
item.description: The Islamic State militant group claimed responsibility for the blasts, which occurred four days after the capture of a suspect in the Paris attacks.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN, AURELIEN BREEDEN and ANITA RAGHAVAN
item.media:description: The Belgian federal prosecutor’s office confirmed the three men in a picture published in the Belgian news media are suspects in the airport bombings.

item.title: Birth Defects Tied to Zika in Panama
item.description: The World Health Organization said the death of a baby with an unusually small head and brain damage was new evidence of the epidemic’s spreading throughout the region.
item.dc:creator: SABRINA TAVERNISE
item.media:description: A health worker fumigated in Veracruz on the outskirts of Panama City last month.

item.title: A Blurry Photo Hints at ISIS Tradecraft
item.description: The men identified as central suspects were decidedly calm, had trimmed beards, wore single gloves that might have disguised detonation handles and probably had bombs in suitcases.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI

item.title: Ebola Fears Shut a Liberian Border
item.description: Liberia closed its border with Guinea as a precaution against the spread of Ebola after at least four deaths from the virus in Guinea.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Bangladesh: Attackers Stab Christian Convert to Death
item.description: Assailants with knives killed the man in northern Bangladesh, the latest in a series of attacks of religious minorities there.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: France: Court Ruling Deals Sarkozy a Legal Setback
item.description: France’s highest court ruled that judicial phone taps between former President Nicolas Sarkozy and his main lawyer were admissible as evidence.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
